resource.chars:
Such appears to me to be the facts respecting the 
structure of the so-called hearts in the 
<u>Terebratulidae <\u> - what I believe to be an
important part of their peripheral circulatory 
system has not hitherto so far as I am 
aware received any notice -
In <u>Waldheimia <\u> the membranous walls 
of the body - the parieto-intestinal bands 
& the mouth, present a very peculiar 
structure - They consist of an outer and an 
inner epithelial layer - of two corresponding 
fibrous layers and between them of a 
reticulated tissue which makes up 
the principal thickness of the layer & in 
which the nerves & great sinuses are imbedded 
The trabeculae of this reticulated tissue 
contain granular & cell-like bodies & 
I imagined them at first to represent 
a fibro-cellular network - the interspaces
